Pupa is a good story, a good manga from what I hear, and Studio Deen put a lot of time and effort into making something good. Then, the censors happened and a regularly timed show that followed the manga got turned into a 4 minute per episode mess of over censoring and incoherence. 
The real shame is that this show could have been great. The art is really well done, the sound is great, hell they even went as far as to record actual eating noises for some of the sound effects. But I don't think you can blame the director, Studio DEEN, or thesource material for the complete fail that was this anime. That all goes on the censors. \n
I've heard people discuss whether the over-use of censoring was a way of DEEN "sticking it to the man," or that the random time jumps and incoherence was also part of the studio fighting back against being forced to censor a show they did not want to censor.\n
When you consider Sakura Trick, it makes some sense. That show is also a Studio DEEN show, also aired winter 2014, and also has some pretty mature themes, but it was able to air un-cut, in full, while Pupa was relentlessly chopped up, to the point where there's some scenes that are almost entirely censors. \n
I would have given this a 1/10, but the art and sound were really well done. I'd love to get a hold of the un-cut full episodes of this, because I feel like it might be worth watching. Sadly, what was aired, is not worth your time, other than for a quick laugh at the comments in the forums.\n

After seeing the movie Ocean waves I decided to check the directors other work and found Pupa . 
I was worried about the fact that the episodes were about 4 minutes long , but I was too curios and Ocean waves managed to fit a handfull of story into 70 minutes wonderfully. 
Reviewing Pupa was really difficult for me so ill give all the pros and cons instead .
Pros:
-The art is kinda neat . The animation is decent and the directing is pretty good . The opening was    gorgeous and the backgrounds were just lovely.
-Music is allright . While the tracks themselvesare good , they repeat them so much it gets kinda distracting and sometimes the music doesnt fit with the mood.\n
Cons: \n
-The story was dreadful. If this was a 90 minute movie I could consider Pupa okay at best , but instead we have : subplots that go absolutely nowhere , a galore of plotholes , flashbacks that end way too early and unexplained character motivations. The 4 minute runtime was definetly among the biggest problems of the show . This is a show that seriously needed to be 2 times longer in lenght. Not helped by the fact that the story itself was very poor .\n
-The characters dont have enough screen time . Other than the 2 main characters and the sorta villain Ai Imari and the main characters mother, none of the other characters have slightest amount of depth , personality or reason for there actions . The show doesnt even explaind the main characters fathers reason for his cruel behavior (wich I wont spoil) and as a result, it just created 11 more layers of cunfusion.\n
-The gore . I know this is an odd thing to conplain about , but the way this show handles all the violence , makes elfen lied seem like Jin roh the wolf brigade . To put it out simply some of the most famous scenes in the show are played in a very calm and semi-erotic tone .Wich is wierd considering SPOILER ALERT!!!!!                                                            all that is happening in those scenes is just one character slowl eating another character from multible parts of his body .Besides that all the other gore is kida silly.\n\n\n
Verdict: \n
Im not gonna lie , despite the show making me feel uncoftorable , I was kinda glad I saw it. Dont get me wrong its a terrible show but at the same time it was a short and memorable experience. You can find the show uncensored on youtube and with your own risk , check it out and you might find something special.

Like I said, the concept to me sounds like it be a fun gruesome delight to watch but its played as some weird fetish?? That's not the only issue. Like I said its SO lazy, mediocre at best.

Anime Series Review No.7
We got this hyped anime series in the year 2013 title PUPA where lots of anime fans and manga fans alike expected this series to be a decent blood gore and horror which I also expect back in those days but yeah anime got delayed but that’s not the problem for this series but the biggest problem that this anime have is the studio who adapted it. Feel free to read my review if you guys want to know why I solely blame the studio and not the original source material.
Plot (3/10)
Reason why the plot is train wreck
- 4 minute duration 
-Turbo Fast Story Progression


That’s the reason why the plot is a train wreck because the short amount of time minus to the opening and ending that lasted half a minute each and we can get a story that is too fast that it’s be too late before you can take it seriously and understand the plot. Horror anime series don’t work that way. If the studio have proper brains they have just made 3 episode or 2 episode Ova with additional fillers to better explain the plot and we will get a anime OVA worth the average plot than this failed anime adaptation we get from a studio who invested there money to lesser content series for the major cash grab. Making PUPA a potentially good anime to be hated for failed adaptation which the studio is the one reason to be blamed in the first place.


Characters (2/10)

Problem why the characters is harder to be liked

- The short duration of the series give very small time for the character to be introduced properly

- The focus is just solely in the siblings but still poorly presented to juice them out to be likable.

- Side characters are just plain food and butchering material to decorate the blood gore scene.


As I did my best to understand the characters from the anime I can’t. But there’s a good side story I liked which explain why the siblings act’s parents acting violently against them but still the duration is too short to explain everything. The anime did explain some part where the manga didn’t in the characters but that’s still not enough cause the manga can fill it up with just one volume or few pages in a chapter.


Sound (2/10)

Nothing Bad in particular to say about this part but I still I dislike it. I dislike the background music cause it’s meaningless cause of the duration of the show.


Art(4/10)

Issues

- Censored Blood Gore is annoying especially if the show duration is also annoying nothing to appreciate anymore. 


The anime is blood gore if that’s not presented well and then the show is pointless.


Enjoyment (2/10)

I would not recommend this show for the purpose that I don’t want people to waster their precious 48 minutes in this anime. Guys I will tell you I just waited for the uncensored version to come out for I won’t be enjoying it a single bit. There are a lot of better anime there to worth investing your time with but not this anime. Trust me guys.

Honestly, when I first got into anime this seemed amazing. But when you go deeper into other shows this one looks horrible. 
The plot is bad, in my opinion. It starts out as mysterious and then Yume and Utsutsu get a virus called Pupa. Yume becomes a flesh eater while her brother has regenerating powers, allowing for Yume to control the virus within her by feeding on him. Horrible anime plotting. 
The art is actually kinda cute, especially when the characters are shown as teddy bears. I guess it isn't really a horror anime...more like pain mixed with fluff.  
I'm going to skip thesound and go into character. I think their back stories are pretty interesting, but the rest of it isn't as entertaining. They are slowly exposing who they really are, but it's also confusing and, as I've said many times, horrible. \n
Basically, I don't really see this as an award winning anime and it deserves the 3.5 star rating it currently has.

Story: 2/10
How do I begin? I guess I'll start with it's biggest flaw. Each episode is only four minutes long (three if you subtract the intro and outro). This adds up to about 36 minutes of material. A little bit more than one episode of a normal anime. This is a downright embarrassment to the Pupa manga. I heard that this show ruined the series for a lot of people who loved the manga. If I had read this after reading the manga, I'd probably give it a two or even a one.
Maybe you're asking why it's so bad that the episodes are so short.This is terrible because it rushes the story along, leaving out tons of material from the manga. The concept of Pupa is interesting, which may be the only reason Story has a two instead of a one. I'll read the manga and hopefully have a better experience.


Art/Sound: 7/10


The art and sound was fine, didn't really have a problem with either.


Character: 2/10


 You don't develop any feeling towards the characters or get to know them. You might want to feel sympathy for the main protagonists, but you don't know anything about them. You don't feel any type of connection to them. There is absolutely no character development in this anime. You get the basic backstory and that's it.  You don't learn anything else about the main characters.


Enjoyment: 1/10


The only thing I enjoyed about Pupa was... hmmmm... there has to be something... oh, there were boobs in episode seven. I guess that counts for something... but it's still too unenjoyable to earn a two. 


Overall: 3/10


This is a poor excuse for an adaptation. who thought that four minute episodes was a good idea? Why leave out so much material? Was it too much money or work to make it at least decent? This could've been a very popular show if it was done right, but sadly it was executed poorly, earning itself a three. Like I said, if I had watched this after reading the manga, I would probably be giving this a two, maybe even a one. You got lucky, Pupa.

This show is barely an anime, and deserves to be called nothing more than a piece of garbage.
I was online, looking for some good horror animes to watch. Someone thought to suggest Pupa, and I was a bit skeptical but looked into it anyway. I mean, what would I lose? Well, I was definitely wrong. My dignity? Pretty sure I lost that the moment I turned on the first episode of this hot mess. Usually, I would have a fit if an anime were only four minutes per episode. Anime deserves so much more! 24 minutes an episode is barely enough. But with Pupa, Iwas more than relieved to see that there were only four minutes per episode.


Story 2/10


Despite being awful and lacking a lot of everything, Pupa had a plot, just not a good one. Whoever thought that incest and cannibalism went together probably didn't have too much of a brain. Actually, maybe this person's idea was good, but it just didn't translate too well on paper. Forget it, I'm not going to try to sugarcoat it. It's just bad. Not only was the plot bad,but it was never fully explained. Maybe because there were only four minutes to an episode?


Art 4/10


This will probably be the nicest thing I have to say about Pupa, but the art wasn't horrible. It wasn't amazing either, but it wasn't horrible. 


Sound 1/10


Oh yes, the awful sounds of a young cannibal eating her brother's flesh, what could be better? Probably anything. Every time she was about to eat him, I would cringe and just wait for it to be over. It's rare that I have a problem with the sounds that a gruesome anime has in it, but this was something else. Something that I never want to hear again.


Enjoyment 1/10


Did I enjoy watching this tale of two siblings' rather awkward interactions? No, I did not. I did not enjoy hearing this little girl lustfully crying out "Onii-chan", each time she took a bite of his flesh.


Overall 1/10


Oh how I wish I could rank this show lower than a 1. Pupa does not deserve my recognition and I really suggest you avoid it at all costs.

Now, At first, upon seeing the art style(that cute imouto!), I was very excited about this anime, so I immediately went to watch it. And my! was I not disappointed! Yume(the aforementioned little sister) is indeed adorable!
...
And that is about the only thing this anime got right.
Pupa Pew-pa
noun
an insect in its inactive immature form between larva and adult, e.g., a chrysalis.
Emphasis on "inactive" and "immature", a very apt description of this anime, making the title completely spot-on.
Story:1
Well, the story is simple: ...Read the synopsis, it's there.
So anyway, it seems pretty clear and easy to follow, but the show makes it unnecessarily complicated with it's ridiculouslyaimless narrative whose only purpose is to shock the viewer. First, it starts by showing us the transformation, wherein the transformed creature literally bursts out of victim, seemingly killing them, monster starts eating everybody, then next thing you know, she's back to her normal, naked self.


"Wait, What?" (image: https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/16634176/random/zetsuenwtf.jpg ignore the caption) was the only thing I could say, 


But wait! it gets worse! the anime then proceeds to alternate between gross out blood and gore, Vorarephilia, and generic, exaggerated child abuse flashbacks, and is pretty inconsistent and secretive about the effects and nature of the pupa virus(hint: withholding information does not make a good mystery, we should at least know how it works, you can leave out where it came from and other details). And that's just the tip of the iceberg, so how about what's underwater? There unfortunately lies the root of this whole mess.



To explain, Stories have something called "concept" and "premise".


For example, Love Live: School Idol Project's concept is


"Girl discovers that her school is scheduled to be shut down, so she capitalizes on a new bandwagon within schools in order to save hers."


 the premise is


 "Girl discovers that her school is closing down, and to do so, the school must attain a certain quota of enrollees to keep itself running.so she decides that she has to prevent that, but she just can't think of anything that would attract students. Just as she was about to give up, she then discovers a new trend on other schools: School Idols, which seems to attract students to schools who have them, this gives the girl 'the best idea she ever had', and the journey begins."



So in other words, concept is "the basic idea of the story", while  premise is "the specific execution of the concept", so how the concept is explored and done, together, they're what makes the story unique.


Pupa unfortunately fails on both account. its concept is "person contracts a virus, turns into a monster" with the premise being... essentially just that, until it arbitrarily decides to backtrack and change things here and there,(the virus was already there at birth, guy somehow gets a virus for no reason, they were abused as children because the virus, they were abused at the request of someone, etc) Seemingly unable to decide how to go about it's established premise.


Normally, the "human turns to monster because reasons" premise isn't too bad (see Ergo Proxy, or heck, even The Hulk and Dr Jekyll and Hyde, which are both a variation of it) but with Pupa's inconsistency and confusing narrative, it obviously sets itself up for failure.


What's even worse than all of these, is that underneath it's premise, is a generic child abuse story featuring sociopathic abusers and abusees, with the theme of... it's not really clear what the theme is, when there seemingly is no message other than "man-meat tastes good" and "we must pity sociopathic killers because the ones abusing them are worse". Really though, who am i kidding, this show is devoid of any meaning whatsoever. or if it had one, it surely did a terrible job getting it across.




Art 4


the art is decent. everything is colored as if it were done with colored pencils, giving the anime a sort of "childish", innocent look. contrast with it's dark, bloody content, it makes for a pretty good juxtaposition of opposites...


except the art team screwed up in the design department. The monster design looks pretty lame, even "ugly cute"(like PvZ zombies) and not intimidating at all, this may be intentional because of who transforms, but it surely waters down the supposed transformation of a person into a horrid creature. the environments were all pretty standard, with only Maria's inner sanctum standing out in it's uniqueness(the statues were a nice touch). The characters were drawn in the most "anime-ish" way possible, so you can be forgiven if you mistake any of the characters here for someone else(Hey, Utsutsu! what are you doing in Yumekui Merry?).



Sound: 3


Good voice acting on all the female characters(Yume swallowing, Yume being cute, Maria's lady tone, Sachiko's cold tone) (and utsutsu being protective, the rest of the men are forgettable) are unfortunately wasted on this drivel. the death screams are not too cheesy. The music, on the other hand, though completely forgettable, are fitting at least.


Characters: 1


There are no characters in this story. only personality-less archetypes, or "cardboard cutouts" as some would call them(damn, Nagi no Asukara raised my bar high! and i mean both my bars). There's the battered Aniki who swears to mamoru his sibling, the battered imouto who is a moeblob, the sexy femme fatale with an agenda(when have they never had an agenda?), the guy in shades who is an assistant, the abusive megane father, the submissive mother, and the generic faceless soldiers and generic faceless mad doctors. I think that's everyone. Literally EVERYONE here has generic flaws and goals. Of course, it would have been better if these flaws and goals were expanded upon, they would have seemed more unique, but with less than 5 minutes to tell each episode, it simply isn't possible... then, could they have just made these people less like puppets playing their roles and more like people acting out their instinct? Maybe, but of course, this seems to be yet another intentional flaw, but doesn't work because there's nothing likeable about ANYONE here... except Yume's cuteness, which Saya of Saya no Uta surpasses eitherway.


But... characters don't normally need intricate backgrounds to be likeable, just a clear personality and standout characteristic makes them seem more appealing, if not realistic. e.g. an abusive person who comes up with unique ways to torture someone can be likeable for his creativity. if you've read Mai-chan no Nichijou(aka Mai-chan's Daily Life, read it for the meme), there's this "President of 'A' Country" who invented an AAAAAWWWWRRRIIGHT way to inflict psychological and physical harm to a pregnant person, all while smiling like an child playing with his toys. he's a horrible person, but he's likeable for his unique methods. basically it's like "admiring the villain's for being an entertaining villain" in a way. I mean who doesn't like The Joker of Batman? Zod of Superman? Lordgenome of TTGL? Majin Boo of DBZ?


Enjoyment: 7


OK, here comes the weird part: I actually had fun watching this show! remember the zetsuenwtf(from Zetsuen no Tempest) pic above? I had that expression the entire time I was watching(marathon) this miniseries. so at the very least, there is entertainment value on this. I was mostly having fun watching Yume eat in the most suggestive and seductive way(I was about to have dinner when marathoning the show, figured I needed an appetizer, it worked, sorta). and on Maria's crazy ramblings and standing around. The rest of the show though... I'd rather forget since it's mostly just pictures of bloody dismembered bodies, seriously. all the budget went into Yume eating.


This should have been titled "Isshoni Eating: Nantaimori with Yume-chan" with all the blood and gore removed and replaced with sweets, and Yume eats on the audience's naked body using her mouth and this would easily be a 10/10 slice of life anime.


So why would anyone watch this, anyway? if they got reeled in by the cute imouto, they're in for some treat. if you expect anything more than "cute girl", you're in for a huge disappointment.


verdict? 3 if calculated, but that would be too generous since the only element I liked is the imouto, so 2.

I heard how bad it was, which is probably why I decided to watch it. Also, marathoning the series would only be like 30 minutes of my time. So at like 1 am today, I started Pupa. 
I will be the first to admit that I am absolutely a biased reviewer. I like pretty art and style-content dissonance, which is why my evaluation is all over the place. Nevertheless, I will try to explain myself.
The 3-minute format, predictably, was a disservice to a horror piece like this. It's simply not long enough to be truly tension-building. Also, the episode content was all over the place.There was a loose sense of continuity, and the series ended on something that felt like a mid-season filler. Plot points were thrown in and then abandoned, so I wasn't really sure where the story was going and what it was doing.


I actually liked the art style. While the big-eyes thing is usually not my deal, I think the innocence the style conveyed contrasted nicely with the (attempted) horror. I liked the watercolor-y background, and the character designs weren't the worst. Also, the teddy bear imagery was a good inclination at the innocence of these kids. Likewise, the music wasn't too bad either. I like the innocence in the sound that contrasted with the content. However, the munchy-munchy sounds were gross and way too wet.


The characters were weak at best. They were reduced to an imouto-oniichan complex with some cannibalism thrown in. They never developed beyond the siscon relationship, which came out of nowhere after the first couple of episodes and dominated the narrative.


There was way too much crammed into 3 minutes. If this was mindless vore and cannibalism, I would have been fine. Even the oversexualized take on the cannibalism would have been fine. However, the incest completely ruined it. Sexualized incest has its place, and it isn't in a vore/horror 3-minute short that doesn't even have time to develop itself.. Also, the censorship sucked, plain and simple. Sometimes, more than half the screen got blocked out. If you're gonna advertise as a vore or horror, you've gotta deliver, especially since that's all the series has going for it.


I told myself that, even if it was bad, at least it was only 30 minutes of my time. 30 minutes is way too much time for this trainwreck, but at least I'll understand why people hate it so much. Given a full 24 minutes per episode and removal of all censorship, the series might have saved itself. Maybe.

WARNING: IF YOU HAVE A WEAK STOMACH OR ARE EATING WHILE WATCHING THIS SHOW IS NOT FOR YOU.
This show suffers from MANY issues:
Incomplete, the story is abrupt, cut short, and doesn't leave much to think about either.
Side characters are COMPLETELY without development. Mains are mostly undeveloped as well, however they get SOME credit since they are shown to care about one another a lot, and given reasons as to why they do.
Those are the main two objective issues with the show. The few reasons I find that others can't find ANY enjoyment in the short series are simply that the show handles taboo topics veryheavily.


For example, the siblings show a VERY close relationship to one another, possibly incestuous even, but never shown directly on screen, so it's hard to tell.

However, *SPOILER ALERT* their sperm and egg cells are combined to make a "monster child" that we never see in the show. Said child is not made through the consent of our main characters and is made without their knowledge.

Even so, the relationship is there, and clearly affects motives of the two characters, and I completely understand the hate for it.


The other taboo subject that is obvious and an extreme deal-breaker for many, is the cannibalism. The main characters both play a large role in this, making it especially hard to swallow *wink wink*.

The girl eats human flesh, tearing others apart at times with her monstrous powers. The boy gets eaten by her, since his powers allow his body to constantly regenerate.


While the cannibalistic subject matter was not too much for me to handle personally, I can absolutely see why it could be for others, it's quite disgusting.



All in all, the reason I found this mildly entertaining, is because the art style is good, the music is fantastic, and the premise is really cool to me (even if it went a bit wasted due to the very short run time.)

This anime makes me truly angry!
The idea is actually okay, it looks like an interesting story however it was completely ruined...
The length of the episodes is just ridiculous, how is it suppose to create that tension we are supposed to feel in horror animes/movies if 2/3 of the episode is the opening and ending songs? Which aren't good either.
The plot is all mixed up, though I guess we couldn't except much from 4 minute long and just 12 episodes.
The only thing I truly enjoyed was the last episode because it was cute and funny which is rather bad since it's supposed to be a horrortype.\n\n
They rushed this anime because it had been announced for a while and yet they kept delaying, or so I read. But I wish they delayed and actually made a good anime than this, it's very disappointing.\n\n
Maybe in the future someone will re-make this anime and hopefully it will end up better than this crap.

The art is worse than the manga of the same name! They look very unappealing!
The music of the opening and of the ending are the only things I liked about the anime.

There no enjoyment in any part of the anime! One of the episodes can torture a person.
Overall: DON'T WATCH THIS!!

It's odd how universally hated this one is.
I mean, I guess not entirely odd. It's kind of a rushed clusterfuck of good ideas and concepts, sprinkled with generous amounts of incest hints, so I can see how people would fail to see the core beauty that lies in this cesspool of gorey goodness. Much like a very good cake that fell on the floor one too many times and now looks like nothing but a big pile of shit. But hey, it's still sugary and creamy and whatever-flavour-suits-you on the inside, despite looking like crap and not being too pleasing on the eye.
Not sure ifthat analogy works at all but I guess what I'm trying to say is that Pupa isn't really that terrible to look at. It is terrible in terms of me squirming the fuck out of my chair whenever there's living tissue being devoured but I'd wager that's pretty normal, and was otherwise pretty interesting, nearly captivating, to see. Well animated, even. Heck, the soundtrack was kinda cool and VAs weren't fucking annoying as hell.


As a not necessarily relevant point, I'm 104% sure there is a vast amount of people getting off to this shit. For every one of my "nopes", there's a person getting a happy ending.


It's been much too many years since this aired, so there's little point in trying to point out how not-entirely-horrible this one is but I guess i just wanted to put it out there. Not so bad. Short enough to be worth a watch.

I really. Really. Wanted to like this anime. When I read the summary for this I instantly thought "This has to be at least an 8" because it sounded SO GOOD. Unfortunately this anime is incredibly poorly done. Everything seems so incredibly rushed- i mean did they really think they could make a decent anime with 4 min episodes? 
The story  just wasn't there. The episodes ended so fast and just jumped to another random spot in the next one there's no keeping up. There are so many unanswered questions and it's extremely frustrating. It feels like I'm watching a recap / summary ofwhat each episode should have been.


The art was pretty unique imo. I kinda liked it actually.


The characters... I don't even know who some of them are supposed to be. Another result of these 4 minute episodes that have absolutely no time to explain anything at all. There's so much stuff going on it's hard to keep track of everything. I really REALLY wished they went more in depth on the characters' backgrounds.


I somewhat enjoyed this anime I honestly think everyone's being a bit too hard on it. It's not the worst thing in the world. I would actually recommend watching it seeing as how it's not even an hour long to watch the entire thing. I had such high hopes for this and was incredibly disappointed. But don't get me wrong, it was pretty interesting to watch.

Oh boy, this did not fail to confuse the crap out of me. I didn't have any expectations for this because I haven't heard of this show/manga before and since it was 4 minutes per episode, I thought "Eh what the hell, why not?" I heard the manga is decent but I can't confirm that myself since I never read it. Also fun fact: in Polish the word Pupa means bum. Bum as in Ass. Anyway... 
Story: 2 
The story was confusing and all over the place. All I got from it was that there is a girl that is a flesh eating monster andshe keeps feasting on her onii-chan so that she doesn't harm anyone else (I guess?). The story, as I mentioned before, is a mess and I don't get it.

Sound: 5

Again meh. The Opening and ending songs are nice, and the voice acting in general was fine.


Character: 2

The character development is non existent and the main characters act the same throughout the show. You will not feel any sort of attachment to the main characters what so ever. It's only established that they are siblings that are on another level of close and that the little sister likes to feast on her big bro's flesh and that the big bro is like eat me all you want. Also he is a monster too so his flesh grows back.

It's bad, very bad. But it sounds ok and it visually looks like some effort was put into the art at least. It was very gory, but scary? Nah, It was forgettable and could probably only scare a kid. I recommend you watch it, as much as I recommend you watch boku no pico. So I don't recommend it.

I watched the uncensored all in one go. Not the best, not the worst. It's aight. It's only shocking if this is your introduction to horror/psychological horror. But if you're into dark and creepy, you'll like it, just for what it is. Apparently not a great adaption so maybe get the manga after.

There's clearly sexual allegory that was desired but maybe not effeciently told. Art is fine, generic. Sound was eh. Dissonant soundtracks are neat but this was a bit blatant. Character was meh.I dunno, I still liked it. It's a wild and creepy ride that, while I wouldn't go on it again, I'm glad I didn't pass up.

It feels weird to write my very first review on what I'd like to call, one of the most disappointing shows I've ever watched. The title itself felt interesting and needless to say, it was a recommendation from one of my friends. I watched and tried my very best to find in myself some sort of appreciation for the anime but very unfortunately, I didn't. Regardless of how new I am in the world of anime, it was clear in my senses that Pupa would always be one to include in the list of worst anime.
Story - 2
The story revolves on the supposed struggle oftwo siblings as the older brother watched his younger sister become a flesh-eating monster and how their life became miserable after that. The story is decent at this part, as the premise was simple and can set the atmosphere for the series of events to come. The problem was how to develop the story and lay out the details of that struggle. I am that type of viewer who does not really care about how unique the story is or how interesting the concept of the anime is; what I want is for the anime to successfully tell me how things happened in a clear and artistic way. This is where Pupa sucked the hardest. The story was very sloppy and unclear, different events with no clear explanations were showed wihout creating any real difference in the main storyline, and jumps from one event to another were made with previous events left unresolved, not to mention that those events weren't foreshadowed in the first place. In fact, there was no clear resolution at the end of the story. That's what was most frustrating. It merely showed a bunch of moaning and biting and blood splatter and gross scenes which don't even make sense. If you look at the scenes assuming that you don't know the anime, you would notice that the foundation that connects the story is the fact that a girl has monstorus flesh eating powers and she has this sister-complex brother who would do stupid pointless things to protect him. It even felt like the story was written for the sake of the anime having a story. So basically, the premise was decent but it was utterly wasted.


Characters - 3

There was no character development, that's all. Based on the resolution of the story, the only personality prominent is the sister complex of the brother and the helplessness of the sister. Other characters which could have been significant and created an impact to the storyline were also wasted. The struggle of the characters meant nothing because they always "went with the flow" rather than puller of strings of the plot. However, am I the only one who finds Yume hot? But that does not change my view of the characters: WASTED.


Art and Sound - 4

Nothing to say about it, because I really don't care about it. Let me just say that the animation was inconveniently unique and the sound mostly consisted of blood splatter and biting and moaning sounds. However, it was decent enough to jive with the atmosphere Pupa is trying to convey.


Overall

Everything had the potential to be developed. I felt disgusted with the way they handled the rest of the show. It was shit, honestly.

Pupa, I needed to edit this review after getting around to watching the final episode. There will be spoilers. But I have been told the manga was better.
The bad. Well, now that I've thought about it the gory aspect went from ballsy to just kind of stupid. I thought it would turn out to be that series that has a bunch of disturbing content and then tells a good story, but it really doesn't. Though I assume this is a "go read the manga" sort of thing if I want to know how this series ends, well I'll go read that, but if a companyis going to pull that sort of thing, then why don't you just go and read the manga instead of watching the anime. There were so many questions I had that I wanted answered, but they never will be, unless I read the manga. But the ending was just so bad, and was an insult to the people that had become invested after sitting through that sixth episode. It was also much too rushed, and they didn't explain why characters were being attacked, and all those little things that actually make a series good. But what pissed me off the most is that this series had unused potential, it could have been amazing, but it failed to do so.


The good. The music and art were amazing, I have to give it that. I could find myself really enjoying the music, well, the half minute long opening theme, but since the episodes are so short, it counts for pretty much the whole soundtrack, but the other music generally fit with the scenes they were in. And I really enjoyed this style of art direction.


Final Verdict:

If you have nothing else to watch it's fine, if not just for the art direction and soundtrack. But the story, character development, and my overall enjoyment were pretty low.


6.3/10

How exactly does one describe Pupa? Perhaps as the anime equivalent of a shock site? Or maybe Aki Sora meets Elfen Lied with a bit of Tokyo Ghoul thrown in for good measure? 
One thing is for certain: Pupa had a lot of potential. A previous work by Studio Deen, the first season of Higurashi, is in the top 10 horror anime on all of MAL. The storyline stood out looking at a seasonal chart before it aired, and the artwork is pretty great.
However...
STORY (3/10):
Pupa was given less then an hour to tell its story, and it's clear from the get-go the series simply doesn'twork in this format. Entire episodes seem wasted, and it seems like every episode ends right before things might get interesting. 


It's also worth noting that Pupa is based off a five-volume manga, which is a bit longer then what less then an hour can properly adapt, and that this manga has a significantly higher score then the Pupa anime (as of this writing).


ART (7/10):


If you can give Pupa credit for anything, it's the artwork. This series looks really nice. The facial expressions for the characters are spot-on, and I love the unique format the show's backgrounds took on. I also thought the teddy bear scenes worked well for the series portraying its more grimdark/extreme moments.


However, I must take a few points off for the ridiculous extent of the gore at times (it sprays literally everywhere), as well as some ridiculous fanservice ("Okay, this scene has some skeevy undertones, but it seems like it's being played for horror...and now 3/4th of the screen is a bent over short-shorts closeup. Isn't this girl like 12?")


SOUND (5/10):


The voice acting and music are decent to pretty good, but I really could have lived without the sucking sounds as Yume eats her brother several times. They're cringy and unpleasant.


CHARACTER (3/10):


Another thing that Pupa suffers from due to its short length is that there's no time to become attached or interested in any of the characters. The series focuses a lot on the abuse the main characters received as children, however I had to learn reading online that the manga fleshes out the father character significantly, and explains a bit as to why he is the way he is. Pupa leaves out several details from its manga like this that are quite important.


ENJOYMENT (3/10):


The feeling you'll get after watching Pupa will probably be of disappointment.


OVERALL (4/10):


In conclusion: is Pupa a highly flawed, disappointing anime? Yes. However, is it the worst anime ever? Probably not. There are worse. Trust me.


---


CONTENT ADVISORY: Pupa features frequent graphic violence, over-the-top gore, mature themes, and lots of pseudo-sexual scenes between a brother and sister. Mature audiences only.

Let me start off by saying that I only watched this anime for the guro. I'm a fan of erotic gore, and that is what I got. I also began with very low expectations anyway, since I've heard about how bad this anime is, so this may be a more positive review.
Story: 1
Each episode was only 4 minutes, which was too short for a 12 episode anime that seems to be aiming to be serious and dark to develop a story. I have never read the manga, and I couldn't understand what was going on. I'm still wondering where and why that guy tortured thebrother and . . . how did Maria (if it was her, anyway) get sperm and egg cells from the brother and sister! Why would she impregnate herself with the monsters. . . ? I did find the end episode to be quite adorable, though.


Art: 5


I enjoyed the overlay of the paint brushes, and I also really liked the look of the characters, even if some may argue most anime characters look like it. I cringed anytime the sister was eating. It just looked . . . really bad to my eyes.


Sound: 4


The opening theme, which was dark, artistic, and stylized, was one I never skipped. I adore it! I dislike the ED, however.


Character: 1


The characters don't develop; they stay the same, for the most part. The brother and sister's relationship just throws incest fanservice at you. A lot of characters are useless; we don't learn anything about them.


Enjoyment: 7


As aforementioned, I came to this anime expecting guro, and that's what I got. Blood, guts, torture, it's all there. Lots of screaming. While the plot content may have not been enjoyable, the mindless fanservice, of a very special kind, was entertaining.


Overall: 3


The story and characters don't even bother to stand up to fall short, but the guro and incestous undertones willl probably entertain at least someone. If that's your thing, check this anime out! If not, stay far away.

There are a couple reasons why I felt compelled to make Pupa my first review on MAL. After hearing many choice words about this anime, I thought I should watch it myself, it being only twelve 4 minute episodes and me appreciating a good psychological horror. Seeing how low it was rated and it being compared to Mars of Destruction, I had very low expectations. However, I was somewhat surprised at the storyline which performed well delivering a disturbing horror piece despite its poor execution in areas.
The story, which succeeded in supplying me with the disturbing, terrifying, and intriguing horror I was looking for mostlikely fell short to many viewers because it requires thought and piecing together a puzzle. The episodes seemed jumbled and out of order in many places, which to me added a little more to the psychological aspect. The beginning few episodes went with the kind of jump scare horror reaction at the end with something bloody happening, the middle a disturbing look at the life of these siblings living with the Pupa virus, and the end the ambiguous conclusion followed by an odd final episode apparently showing an event from the childhood of Utsutsu and Yume. YES, the story was hard to follow at times, but I also felt it supplied what I was looking for from the genre. (5/10)


The art was fine, and nothing special. More expressive and abstract at times, sometimes the characters looked weird. I felt it worked with the psychological aspect with the show. I enjoyed the creative use of teddy bears in place of characters in certain scenes. In terms of the gore, it was up to par and sufficiently disturbed me. (3/10)


The voice acting seemed forced and oddly clashing at the beginning. However, over the course of the show I either got used to it or it improved. The background music is hardly worth mentioning, although I enjoyed the OP. Some of the sound effects, although not excellent really came through at delivering a disturbing atmosphere, especially when Yume feeds. The sexual atmosphere created this way was amazingly creepy and disturbing especially with the incest undertones. (4/10)


The characters were lacking somewhat; if you could piece things together you get the sibling's past, but at times you wondered why a character was even in this anime, as they seemed to have no connection to the storyline. I don't know. If I re-watch it someday, I might catch on more. In terms of the romance some people describe, I did feel emotions between the siblings; the characters weren't flat 2-D cutouts. (4/10)


Overall, considering my enjoyment of this anime, I give it a 4 out of 10. If you enjoy any type of psychological horror like H.P. Lovecraft or just slasher and gore and don't mind a little cannibalism/incest, look past its obvious flaws and give Pupa a try. I felt this anime met its goals of leaving me with a feeling that would be expected from watching any psychological horror genre. If you get too in depth, it is very creepy, if you take it on the surface, it is still weird and chilling. One thing I recommended is watching this over the course of a day or two, don't drag it out as you lose enough between some episodes and will get lost more easily. There is something that can be taken from this show if you are willing to go out there and get it.

I have to admit, when I first heard the premise for this, I was kind of wanting to see it. A sister having to eat the flesh of her brother to remain in control, that is an excellent premise.
This is of course however ruined by the run time ~4 minutes an episode. That's roughly 1 minute less an episode than Hetalia, and Pupa's opening credits are longer so that's even less run time. To compare Hetalia to Pupa is kind of an uneven argument since Hetalia is a Comedy and Pupa is a Horror, but you can get some form of entertainment from hetalia maybea cheap laugh but it did more than Pupa did. And most of it is censored, because flesh eating, they couldn't even throw us a bone with some kind of gore.


Another thing to consider is if the episodes came out weekly (They may have, not sure) that makes it difficult to truly be interested when you get barely any information from each episode, as if getting one word of a sentence a week. You just don't care anymore.


Tokyo Ghoul has a similar premise to this (Only episode 2 has aired at the time of this review) but as a traditional 23/24 minute run time we're getting more character development, story development and the lore of the world in general.


In summary: Avoid Pupa at all costs, it's a waste of: Time, memory, breath, battery power and internet history.

Watch Tokyo Ghoul instead, it does this ALOT better

*This is my first review, and i'm not so good in english, so sorry for grammar mistakes.*
Ah. Pupa, the 4-minutes long anime, wich 2 minutes are used for the OP and ED... I was so hyped for this anime, since a friend recommended it to me 2 months before the first episode was released, the story looked interesting and i was looking foward to it.
When i watched the first episode, i felt really confused, and i knew that this series was going to be so bad, i dropped this anime for like 6 months and then started watching it again for the sake of thisreview, so yhea...


STORY: The story was really bad, Yume and Utsusu, two bullied siblings that got infected from a virus named "Pupa", and now Yume needs to eat humans in order to satisfy herself.


But then it goes everywhere, from a girl that wants to do experiments with them, to another organization that wants to use their powers to "upgrade" mankind, and a simply thief that wants to kill them, Oh! and a simple episode dedicated to Yume eating her own brother while saying "Onii-chan", that's it, Tata!


CHARACTERS: These things are all messed up: 

Yume; She is the only character that turns into a monster, and therefore she needs to eat humans to fill her hunger, and then all she does is eat her brother's insides, all the rest of the series, ugh.

Utsusu; This is probably the lamest brother i have ever seen, instead of finding a cure, he decides to transform his own body into the daily lunch of his dear little sister, so she can't eat anyone else, lame and poor writing...

The rest of the cast dies between 3 seconds after it's appearance, there is a mad girl called Maria (i think) that uses the sperms of Utsusu and the ovule of Yume (Don't know how did she get them) to get pregnant, so she can give birth to a demon, well too bad because it's the last time we see her.

And the mother, that tried to kill Yume when she was a baby because we learn that she was already infected, and the father is just a bad father.


--So yhea, the show is all about Yume eating her brother's flesh.


SOUND: Simple music made with simple instruments, the music repeats itself in every episode, i only heard like 6 differents songs through the series, and the sound effects are nothing special, they even used the sound effect from Sunrise intro, lol


*OVERALL: Pupa is a terrorific series, just don't watch this anime if you don't want to get disappointed, or you can just simply watch it to laugh because how poorly is made, and after completing it and realizing that you could have spent all that time to make yourself a sandwich.

This one is SO bad that is actually good. Yeah, I ENJOYED it.
It's basicaly about a monster girl who eats people. And her own brother - everyday. 
An anime about a girl who eats her own brother everyday. Got it? It also has some secret organizations but who cares, the story is awlful, who would watch this for anything other than the bizarreness?? 
About the art... The gore is kinda ok, but the background art looks like it was made by my grandfather. He had no arms. The only point I think is really good is the soundtrack, I enjoyed the BGM. The rest is...A monster girl eating her own brother and blood and worms and what the hell did I just watch.\n\n
Listen to me, watch this one (uncensored!!!!!) in the night, like 2 a.m., get a drink and relax. I laughed the entire time. I will remember Pupa for the next 3 generations of my family, and will still be laughing and asking "what the f did I watch".

When I heard of Pupa I was actually a little excited because of the manga. However I soon realized Pupa was only going to have 12 episodes each with 4 minutes, less if you skip the openings and endings. I deeply regret watching it. The MAL rating system of 1 for 'appalling' accurately describes Pupa.
Story-0.5
The story started out okay but went downhill after episode 4 or 5. It ended without an explanation and left me with many questions and plot holes. The order was confusing and four minutes is simply not enough for a horror anime that had more potential. Anybody else wonder what happenedto the pregnant lady?


Art-2.5

The art was poor for our generation but not much to comment about. However it lacked colour. The bloody scenes defied gravity and the scenes kept repeating. The anime had too many censored scenes for a horror/physiological.


Sound-3.5

The opening and ending may possibly be the only pros about this anime. However compared to the other anime that aired during the season, I can only give Pupa a participation award.


Character-0.5

Where do I start? There was absolutely no character development until the last episode and I don't think it should even count. Utsutsu's 'scar' on his face is never explained either. It's your typical story where the brother would do anything for his little sister. With a little twist where the imouto eats her brother's meat and of course he can regenerate because that is how science works.


Enjoyment-0

Out of all the anime I have watched so far in my life, Pupa is the only one I regret. I started it a few months ago and dropped it after episode 4 seeing how bad it was. However as the optimist I am, I decided to continue it hoping to find some character development and an interesting plot. What did I find? Nothing.


Overall-1.4

I can definitely say that Pupa is the worst anime I have ever watched. Pupa is essentially an exceedingly friendly sibling relationship and lots of cannibalism. On a side note, an excellent to get fit would be to do a push-up every time you hear “onii-chan”. Watch Pupa at your own risk.

ALRIGHTY XD REVIEW #2!!! LEGGO. 
I would like to start by providing a HUGE warning for the faint-hearted. I.e; People who dislike the sight of blood, twisted story lines, or simply dislike psychologically inept characters. Ultimately, that's all this anime is. A orgy of everything you could possibly consider morally wrong, combined with a massive blood bath of the like. However, I loved it. Take that as you will. 
First off, the story. Despite my love of mass murder, action, and blood, the plot line was a bit confusing at first. In the first episode, you automatically jump into a school setting, then to apark, where the seemingly sweet and innocent sister, transforms into some sinister, demonic, murderer. WAIT- what? Was my first reaction, however in later episodes it goes on to give a somewhat detailed synopsis of the main sibling's tragic, abused background. Although I enjoyed the feel of the story, my main issue is the half-heartedness  evident throughout the plot. Characters like the researcher Maria-san, and her crew were introduced, leaving the watcher obviously expecting a relevant contribution to the plot, but you're left hanging. It seems as if the creators had an idea they started on, that could've been promising, but sort've left it hanging dry, making you think," Uhm, what was the point of that?" Senseless obstacles can sometimes be entertaining, but in this case, the creator's habit of jumping around without fully developing a point would have to deduct points from the ultimate enjoyment. 


The art was very good! Modern, and the animation itself was well done, as well as intricately paid attention to. You can especially see this in scenes where Yume is feasting on flesh, as not only is her expression not neglected and left blank, but as her jaw moves through a chewing motion, her expression follows suit. Small details such as this make for better quality. Nevertheless, the censors on objects such as the blades, or knives is puzzling, and irritating. 


The music was appropriate for the scenes, such as darker music would be paired with murderous scenes to provide a more eerie feel. However at some parts, too many background noises were apparent, taking away from what was actually happening on screen. Also, in a sentimental scene, which is crucial, the background music was too loud, overpowering the scene itself, when it should be there for support, and as a gentle accent to the character's actions. 


I feel as if the characters were well developed, due to the fact that the watcher is easily able to see what caused a certain action. The blatant appearance of cause and effect, is extremely well played out, but at the same time not overdone. You don't get the feeling the creators were merely adding things as a bonus, but it flows, and fits well with plot. 


Finally, what I DIDN'T like, and the reason certain categories were deducted points although my commentary is positive, is the justification for Yume's insatiable hunger, thus forcing her to feed off of her brother, Utsutsu. The creators attempted to create a strong bond between the siblings, Utsutsu, being the type to do anything for his sister, even sacrificing himself as live bait, which fit well with the main themes. Nonetheless, in scenes where Yume was feeding off of Utsutsu, it was HIGHLY UNNECESSARY to create such sexual imagery, and eroticism. It completely contradicts the main point of the story, and does NOT help the plot whatsoever. Additionally, in episode 12, when Utsutsu states," I love Yume's erotic face when she's done eating. Being live bait isn't so bad.", was just downright disturbing. We've had 12 episodes of full-on hardcore killing as a product of a vicious virus, and all of the sudden it turns into some romantic duty of a loving brother in an incestuous relationship?!? No. Unneeded, and uncalled for. 


Despite that, I did enjoy this anime. Again if you enjoy action, and gore as much as I do, this is an anime for you!!

I really liked the anime, and before explaining why, yes, I read the manga. The manga is better, but the anime is also good (not as good as the manga but ok). First of all, if you've never read the manga, do not watch it. Because you won't understand and will hate it. After reading the manga, you can enjoy this pretty small anime, acclaimed by critics. The opening and ending song are just awesome and soft, and for me the animation was a gift for those who read the manga, like having the "taste" of a real anime. After all, Sayaka Mogi is anew mangaka, and as I searched (not sure) this was his first manga. I think it was proposital to do not explain all in the anime, otherwise the animation wouldn't have 4 minutes of duration~ hope you guys enjoy pupa

ENGLISH - INGLÊS
   It was already expected that by the rating of the anime and by the "Reviews", that would come a bad thing. Unfortunately, it is part of the life of an anime fan, to judge such work not by its cover, but by its real potential without precepts. The anime fails on almost all the categories that I find useful for creating a full experience. The first one, for sure, is the "Plot". I finished seeing this excrement  without understanding what it is, a sister feeding on her brother? The sister who turnsin a monster and her brother tries to help? I have no idea what it is ... Apparently neither the synopsis on the app in which I saw the anime knew, cause it was said that the brother was aiming to restore his sister to normal ... Was this shown in the work? It was not! Now, we are going to the "Plot Development", and I have nothing to say, it was practically the worst thing I've ever seen in my life, I do not understand the existence of so many holes and holes in development. If I wanted to, I could finish "Review", because "Pupa" failed in the most important topics. The characters had something to deliver, but they delivered nothing, interesting characters thrown in the trash and with no function or development. This applies even to the protagonists, whose they were the most developed, and even being the ones that made the most progress, they managed to be a failure, showing a past full of holes to "fill" in an anime in which each episode has 4 (Four) minutes.\n
   We managed to find something not so flawed. We're talking about Dubbing. I consider the only point where they really succeeded in being good, the voices of the protagonists and the extras were not weak, they were normal, but what really caught my attention were the desperate shouts in scenes of torture. At least in that, they went well. I felt in an endless agony to hear (Spoiler) the protagonist's flesh being torn with the teeth of his "little sister", or even in the scene when the scientists plucked their organs. (End of Spoiler). Another point that was lousy but was not the worst is the topic of "Openings and Endings". I swear the opening is cool, but it was introduced randomly when the episode began. Not only does it seem, as it should be a cut song, where they picked up the chorus and smashed it. Already its finalization is a normal basic song that I did not see problems.\n
   Now we come to the topic of "Graphics", and try to guess what the result? Horrible too! They tried to create something a bit more "Dark" and they really succeeded, but something a little darker does not mean that it should have a crappy and rotten animation as was "Pupa". The anime "Steins Gate" managed to create a more "Dark" environment in a splendid way. Another that also achieved such feat was the new film "Fate Heaven Feels". Of course such a "Type Moon" work has enough money to play great graphics and so on, but the ambience in the anime itself has been turned to a dark sphere. The following topic would refer to "OVA's / Fillers", but they do not have the name "OVA", but rather as a normal episode. I'm talking about the last episode, which came to be interesting, showing how the sister got that little flower that is in your head, but try to guess again! It was horrible and badly applied, not to mention that other character that appears, whose has 3 (Three) sisters, if I am not mistaken. For what reason did they show it if they had no premiss, to develop it? They only created their existence in this work, to give the "tickets" to the lottery. I would rather not have been created if I were to appear in such a work.\n
   We're nearing the end. Now the last topic. I'm talking about "Soundtrack". Well, I say it was not the worst or the best. It was there when it needed to, to make the scenes more interesting. Even so, the soundtrack’s rating weighs because of the flaws in the other categories. So thanks me for giving it a rating 4 (Four).\n\n
PORTUGUESE - PORTUGUÊS \n\n
   Já era esperado que pela nota do anime e pelas “Reviews”, que sairia daí uma coisa hórrida. Infelizmente, faz parte da vida de um fã de anime, julgar tal obra não pela glosa, e sim pelo seu real potencial sem preceitos. O anime falha em praticamente qualquer aba em que considero útil para a criação de uma obra. A primeira, com toda certeza, é o “Enredo”. Eu terminei de ver esse excremento sem entender do que se trata, uma irmã se alimentando do irmão? A irmã que vira monstro e o irmão tenta ajudar? Eu não faço ideia do que seja... Aparentemente nem a sinopse do aplicativo na qual eu vi o anime sabia, pois foi dito que o irmão tinha como objetivo restaurar sua irmã ao normal... Isso foi mostrado na obra? Não foi! Agora,  estamos partindo para o “Desenvolvimento de Enredo”, e eu não tenho nada a dizer, foi praticamente a pior coisa que eu já vi desenvolverem na minha vida, não compreendo a existência de tantas falhas e furos do desenvolvimento. Se eu quisesse, já poderia terminar a “Review”, pois “Pupa” falhou nos tópicos mais importantes. Os personagens tinham algo a entregar, mas não entregaram nada, personagens interessantes jogados praticamente no lixo e sem nenhuma função ou desenvolvimento. Isso se aplica até mesmo aos protagonistas, em que foram os mais desenvolvidos, e mesmo sendo os que mais tiveram um progresso, conseguiram ser uma falha, mostrando um passado cheio de furos para “encher linguiça” em um anime em que cada episódio tem 4 (Quatro) minutos.\n
   Conseguimos achar algo não tão falho. Estamos falando da “Dublagem”. Eu considero o único ponto em que realmente conseguiram ser bons, as vozes dos protagonistas e dos figurantes não chegaram a ser fracas, foram normais, mas o que realmente me chamou atenção foram os gritos desesperadores em cenas de tortura.  Pelo menos nisso, eles foram bem. Me senti numa agonia sem fim ao ouvir (Spoiler) a carne do protagonista sendo rasgado com os dentes de sua “irmãzinha”, ou até mesmo na cena quando os cientistas arrancavam seus órgãos. (Fim do Spoiler). Outro ponto que foi péssimo, mas não foi o pior é o do tópico de “Openings e Endings”. Eu juro que a abertura chega a ser legal, mas ela foi introduzida aleatoriamente quando começava o episódio. Não só parece, como deve ser uma música cortada, onde eles pegaram o refrão e botaram porcamente. Já sua finalização é uma música básica normal que não vi problemas.\n
   Agora chegamos no tópico de “Gráficos”, e tente adivinhar qual o resultado? Horrível também!  Tentaram criar algo um pouco mais “Dark” e realmente conseguiram, mas algo um pouco mais sombrio não quer dizer que deva ter uma animação cagada e podre como foi o de “Pupa”. O anime “Steins Gate”, conseguiu criar um ambiente mais voltado para o “Dark” de uma forma esplêndida. Outro que conseguiu também tal proeza, foi o novo filme “Fate Heaven Feels”. É claro que tal obra da “Type Moon”,  tem bastante dinheiro para bancar ótimos gráficos e etc, mas o ambiente no anime em si foi voltado para uma esfera sombria. O tópico a seguir, seria referente aos “OVA’s/Fillers”, mas não possuem, não ao nome de “OVA”, mas sim como um episódio normal. Estou falando do último episódio, que chegou a ser interessante, mostrando como a irmã conseguiu aquela florzinha que fica em sua cabeça, mas tentem adivinhar novamente!  Foi horrível e mal aplicado, sem contar aquele outro personagem que aparece, que tem 3 (Três) irmãs, se não me engano. Por qual motivo mostraram ele, se não tinham como premissa, desenvolvê-lo? Apenas criaram sua existência nessa obra,  para dar os “papeizinhos” para o sorteio. Eu preferiria nem ter sido criado, se fosse para aparecer numa obra dessas.\n
   Estamos chegando ao final. Agora, o último tópico. Estou falando da “Sonoplastia”, no caso, a trilha sonora do anime. Bem, digo que não foi das piores e nem das melhores. Ela esteve lá quando precisava, para deixar as cenas mais interessantes. Mesmo assim, a nota da “Sonoplastia” pesa por causa das falhas das outras abas. Então, agradeça por eu ter dado uma nota 4 (Quatro).

What can I say that hasn't already been said a thousand times? There's no beating around the bush, Pupa is an awful anime. It even has a reputation of being one of the worst anime of all time, which I agree with. It's so devoid of positive aspects I'm convinced the only reason people were able to finish it at all was the series's short length.
Art: This is one of the better aspects of the show and it's still awful. The character designs are mediocre but the backgrounds look like a watercolor painting by a preschooler. It clashes horribly with the much more neatly animatedcharacters and is a general eyesore. The worst thing about the visuals though is the censorship. People watch trashy horror movies for the ridiculous gore. Removing it takes all the fun out of it. And Pupa is incredibly inconsistent with censorship. A pile of dead bodies is ok but a knife isn't.


Sound: Not much to say here. Voice acting, ost, and the opening and ending were all mediocre at best but there's not much to complain about either.


Plot: Wait, you're telling me this anime had a plot? To me it just looked like a bunch of vaguely connected, disturbing, and nonsensical scenes tied together. There isn't even a real conclusion and viewers are left with far more questions and answers. I dislike endings that don't leave anything at all to the imagination but you have to give the audience something. They watched your show till the end and expect something for it. Trying to comprehend this anime's story is frustrating to say the least.


Characters: Honestly, the only notable characters are the main brother/sister duo. And they have no personality. None. The brother is the typical "sweet, protective onii-chan" and his sister is just the helpless and adorable younger sister. That's all there is to them. I couldn't even tell you their names.


Overall: Don't watch this anime. It would only take up about 50 minutes of your time but that time could be spent doing something much better. Like reading a book. Drawing. Watching a superior anime. Masturbating. Just do something else unless you want a perfect example of how not to make an anime. Pupa is a trainwreck from start to finish and is not worth your time.

Looking at all aspects it is lacking in plot, has a little better art than most of the anime I've seen, sound is about what you'd expect, not enough screen time to bond with characters, my enjoyment rating is decent. Mainly because of the art.
It's not as bad as people claim it to be. There's a ton of overreacting, as usual. I see absolutely nothing wrong with the art or sound compared to other anime. I personally actually liked both (voices and art) just fine. There's not much of a plot, but other than that I'm not sure why people are hating on it somuch. Probably because it is strange. In a way it kind of reminded me of the first season of Tokyo Ghoul (haven't finished season two because it is terrible in my opinion), which seems to do some much better because...? The epic fight at the end?


For some reason, myanimelist.net wants unreasonably long reviews so I'm going to have to type some more. I definitely feel like this anime had potential to be something better (like Shiki), but just wasn't well planned out.

I was expecting full episodes that were at least 17+ mins. What I didn't expect was for the episodes to be only around 5 minutes. Eventually, I became happy about this. I was forcing myself to watch it.
The anime had me interested once I read the summary. But, I was actually surprised and a bit disappointed when I started the anime. The plot was somewhat confusing and everything just felt like a jumbled mess. Despite that, I was still able to understand a bit. This fact is what saved this anime.
The art's not bad and neither is the animation. The way thecharacters are suck though. Utsutsu is an ok character. I like how he goes to extreme lengths for his sister. Yume was ruined for me. That one scene when she kept saying "onii-san... onii-san..." instantly got on my nerves. At that point, I couldn't even say that I liked her. Nothing in the anime redeemed her. In my opinion, she wasn't even interesting. She can have a few sympathy points because of the situation she's in though...


Anyway, I hardly remember the other characters. That one woman was somewhat interesting but we didn't get to learn much about her. Also, I wish that we could've learned more about Utsutsu and Yume's parents. I guess this is what happens when you take a manga series and try to make everything fit into 5 minute episodes.

I can't really find a good thing to say about this. There are literally episodes where the only thing happening, is Yume feeding on her brother while he's having incestuous-sounding thoughts about it. This anime is downright disgusting in every aspect of the word.

After reading the manga, I was intrigued to see how the anime would compare. After watching the first episode I was a little disappointed, but I forced myself to finish it out of respect for the manga. The actual premise of the manga and anime is amazing for horror fans like me. Two orphaned siblings relying on each other for survival when suddenly the sister is turned into a disgusting monster.
 I'm not quite sure what it was about the anime version, but I just didn't enjoy it. Looking at the other reviews, it seems like I'm not alone. Maybe the manga is just toogood to be adapted into an anime.

Right before I began watching Pupa, my biggest concern was that it wouldn't be very good considering every episode is around 3 minutes worth of content (4 minutes if you include the credits). Strangely enough, it managed to deliver bite sized depictions of the most twisted scenarios you could imagine, strong enough to make me have to drop the show after watching episode 8. It wasn't a scary show per sei, but it was very unsettling, more so than I usually can handle (I'm not exactly a lightweight when it comes to horror, but since the show cuts everything so much to the point, there'svery little time to mentally prepare yourself if you're bingewatching the show).


Despite all of the negative reviews here on MAL, I don't think Pupa is a bad show. Yes, there's hints of incest, among other seriously messed up topics. Up until episode 8, you never thought things could get any worse and yet they do, not for the story itself but for the actual topics they address. Of course, one of the biggest downsides is the length of the episodes, despite how well they made use of the time. Nothing ever feels like it flows smoothly, instead it feels like you're getting glimpses into this messed up world Pupa revolves around, which isn't bad, but it doesn't make much for an actual story.


Overall, I think if you enjoy gore and horror you'll probably enjoy watching Pupa. The show isn't for the faint of heart, and even some horror lovers like myself will have to tap out early since this show actually managed to make me want to hurl at some of the scenes, but that only goes to show how much of an impression it will leave on you. So, if this sounds like the kind of thing you'd find interesting, don't get discouraged by the negative reviews. Pupa isn't a perfect show, but it's not the worse thing out there either.

Oh my dear heavens, where do I even begin?
I think it's pretty obvious on MAL that this is a notoriously awful anime. And after biting my lip through such a disastrous show, I understand why. 
Although you can easily finish this anime in such a short span of time as the episodes are only five minutes long, it doesn't make it less painful. It's like deciding to run a mile on a bed of cacti rather than walk. Yeah, it makes the pain go away faster, but by the end you're still bleeding and crying and cussing up a storm.
And while I've never read themanga, I have heard from fans of the manga that it is not as bad as this. It's no "Cowboy Bebop" or "Fullmetal Alchemist", but it serves a purpose and caters to fans who enjoy horror manga. And hey, at least the manga knew how to go from point A to point B instead of just pooping out scenes willy nilly. So if you are a fan of the manga, I deeply apologize that this is the anime adaptation that you have received. I imagine this is the same disappointment and disgust if a new film adaptation of "To Kill a Mockingbird" cast Pauly Shore as Atticus Finch.\n\n
While I detested Pupa, I can't give it a 1. It's still not the worst thing I've ever seen. To a lot of people, yeah, this is probably the worst. But to me, I think there's worse out there. I think it's because I still hold onto hope that maybe someday, a brave soul will scoop the Pupa manga into their arms and give fans the adaptation they deserve. Until that day comes, avoid this like the bubonic plague.

I never read the manga of the same name but I have heard of Pupa. Found out about it somewhere in the beginning of this year and it interested me a little. So I decided to watch all twelvr episodes....and the only thing I was happy about was that I didn't eat anything during the entire time, because I know for a fact I would have puked.
For one thing, the story is all over the fucking place. Like literally all over the place cause it jumps back and forth and back and forth through random things and barely explains anything if not everything. I justsat in the chair watching on my Ipad constantly trying to figure out what was even going on in this crapfest. Granted it only had 4 to 5 minutes at best for each episode so they couldn't tell a full story, but my god!


As for the characters....I just have 4 letters that I could use for them. WHAT THE ACTUAL FUCK! The characters have zero. I repeat zero character development. If there was some, I definitely didn't see. It wws basically the cliche caring brother whose sister is a demon child and loves eating him while saying "Oni-chan, Oni-chan, Oni-chan" Over and over again. I wanted to rip my ears off and wanted to bang my head against a freaking wall after hearing that over and over and over. And her brother just lets her eat him. Oh and I should add he has regenerative powers, so he is a demon child like him to. And their relationship is way beyond the sibling level. There are side characters in it, but who honestly cares about them? Who honestly gives a damn


As for animation and sound...eh. The art is average at best and the sound...I have heard worst so it is okay for what it is.


Overall I would not recommend this to anyone. Like I said the episodes were like 4 minutes long at best and they jumbled it up all over the place that it isn't even funny. I haven't read it, but you might as well read the manga since it goes mr in depth on the story and explain things better. Or that's what I heard atleast. But go check it out
