Man, this anime sure was bad, not the worst one I've seen in my life (which is big order), but it definitely is one of the most confusing and disgusting ones that I've seen.
I'll probably read the manga to see how awful of an adaptation this is. Since having 3-5 minutes to adapt the entire manga is going to turn into an awful adaptation (they should've either go for a movie adaptation or keep insisting on having 12 episodes).
But even then, having to read the manga to even understand the plot of it doesn't excuse the bad adaptation. Since the adaptation should at least begood on it's own merits and have the same explanation as in the manga.


The bare minimum of a plot that i got from this the following: 

The sister becomes infected by the pupa virus, which seems to turn people into monsters due to an infected puppy and some red butterflies, but then it turns out that she was actually a monster from the very beginning, which is a very stupid twist and a serious plothole. Then the brother becomes infected because the sister ate him and for some reason the virus got into him even if the rest of the people who got eaten by her didn't have the virus.

Maybe it was because the scientists tried to help the brother with a drug, but that doesn't give a good explanation of it.


And thus in order to protect her sister and because he didn't want her to eat more innocent civilians he becomes food for her.


Then a lot of filler happens (onii-chan no niku or her eating her brother, the worst filler they could've ever put and could've adapted more stuff in it) then another medical corporation kidnaps both of them and they decide to experiment on the brother by removing parts of his body, then he kills them and him and her sister reunite, go back to school and he still let's the sister to eat him instead of finding out the purpose of the virus or if they even care to go back to normal. And instead of ending there they just add another filler episode of him winning a prize.


That's a very shitty plot if you ask me. And if we add the scenes of cannibalism "incest" (which was not pleasant to look at all), the filler episodes and the fact that most of the things aren't explained properly, then we have one of the worst animes of all time.


The only good thing I can say about it is that this can serve as an example as to how not to adapt a manga .﻿

I give it about 5 or 6 overall for enjoyment, i recommend it if you like viruses that turn people into monsters, or want to see a refreshingly odd anime featuring incestuous sibling cannibalizing. It's only 30 minutes, that is both a strength and weakness, because there rarely is a lull, and you don't lose much by watching it, but a lot of the story is left out.
The anime actually has a decent start, but only gets more disjointed as time goes on. Characters and plot points are introduced, then forgotten without explanation. Some people may like that, but i found it disappointing when thingsstart getting interesting and then a plot line is dropped.


It was touching to see the relationship of the two main character siblings., how they stand up for each other through hardship and trials. Unfortunately, the little sister has not much to say and doesn't seem to think much at all.

I thought it was interesting how by depending on each other, they literally have a symbiotic relationship by the end, by endlessly regenerating his body, he can feed his little sister without her having to kill innocent people!

It sure gets points for originality.


I thought the art was fairly decent, not QUALITY by any means.

This is basically vore porn with inescapable overtones of sibling incest. 
The characters are two dimensional and the story has no structure, no resolution, and no development. 
It's very sexual and odd and pointless. But, because I am a depraved, I love it.
There are three reasons to watch Pupa:
1) You love some cannibalism and violent horror. You also can't figure out what to watch next so you could use a horror "snack" of 4 min episodes.
2) You are tickled by the absurdity of some anime. The gratuitous violence and psuedo-sexual brother-sister relationship is hilarious. Watch with your friends, have a laugh, and/or make some gifsfor your tumblr or whatever.\n\n
3) You've watched all the vore and sibcest hentai that you could get your hands on. Now you're searching for something to scratch that itch. \n
Pro tip: if the cannibalism isn't a turn-on, just listen to the audio and forego looking at the video. It's basically groaning and squelching with constant "Onii-chan" repetition.\n

Needed to be twice as long to be viable in any kind of way. Good basic concept, but I suppose that they were badly funded, so the entire story lacked elements of contrast resulting in a sloppy show.
Some scenes maybe hard to swallow due to gore and adult themes. Also on that note, it is interesting to see a horror/psych anime so haphazard in the way it capitalizes on its gore content. The art work follows a similar trend with some extremely beautiful drawings (Like in the opening) follow by some lazy doodles (especially in the background). The music is nothing special, although the lyricsof the opening theme are good enough to atleast set the mood for the show (a 30 second tease).The ending theme is worthless.

I've never written a review before but I thought I'd give my input on this anime thus far.
I feel as though this anime has received low ratings because it is not what people had originally expected it to be.  The episodes are very short, about four minutes long.  It's almost as if you're just skipping through a long episode of something to get the gist of it.  Because of this, there isn't much time to develop background details or characters, making the show bland.  I'm sure that if the episodes were as long as a regular anime, this anime would bea lot better.  There is an interesting plot to it, if you're into creepy psychotic things.


It makes me sad that the art is so bad.  The blood is too fake looking and the backgrounds are pretty terrible at some points.  Though, at other points the art is alright.


The opening and ending themes are nice.


This anime is sort of a disappointment, but I can also imagine it to be an awesome anime if the episodes were long enough to put in detail.  To enjoy this anime you need to use your imagination, I suppose.

If you have a strong constitution, please do not shy away from this anime. I find that it is a much under-rated show, and with it only being a total of less than 45 minutes, even if you are a bit weak-stomached you can still make it through. 
It may be that I went into watching this anime with absolutely the worst expectations that I could have, but in the end I really enjoyed watching Pupa. I found the story to be entertaining and captivating, with the art and sound to be a bit more than fair. I would have liked to have seen morecharacter development as we see the reference of where Maria thinks that the children would really like to meet their actual parents. Also would like to see where the story line would have gone with the monster that Maria is breeding. In addition to seeing the story continued, the other aspect that could be improved on would be that the story is a bit discontinuous, but I have seen animes that are much more disjointed.
